Author: TheQuarantinian

Comment: It was an administrative warrant. That's a warrant from DHS that they create themselves. The judge asked if it was a judicial warrant (aka, "a warrant signed by a judge" as referenced above). There are limits to what this "warrant" gets them...  For example, an administrative warrant does not authorize them to enter private property... (like your home, or a non public area of a business like a kitchen). You also don't have to actively help them if they show up with only an adminsitrative warrant asking if an employee is working that day, for example.   It is not the same as an arrest warrant signed by a judge that has an actual standard of proof behind it. This is basically just a name on a spreadhseet coming up then being printed on company letterhead.  That said, whether letting someone use a jurors exit will count as actively undermining "law enforcement" (even though its a civil agency with a civil enforcement mandate) when they are operating in a public area will be the question... it's not about the piece of paper.

Comment: I can certainly appreciate the technical differences. Boo on the media for not being 100% accurate.  However, that there was "a" warrant does not appear to be in dispute. The chief judge's office seems to have recognized the warrant as valid and did not dispute it. They were not seeking to enter private property.  Dugan, on the other hand, reported stated simply "a warrant was not presented in the hallway on the 6th floor." She didn't say that a "valid" warrant wasn't presented, she didn't say that a "warrant signed by a judge" wasn't presented, she seems to have claimed that there was no warrant of any kind.  You are right - it isn't about the paper, it is about whether or not her actions constitute obstruction of justice. It certainly appears though that a sworn office assisted somebody in evading arrest.
